claims.text: Human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
claims.context: General statement about climate change causes.

claims.text: The main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect.
claims.context: Explains the primary mechanism behind climate change.

claims.text: Gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere.
The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution.
claims.context: Quantifies the increase in CO2 due to human activities.

claims.text: Ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, causing sea levels to rise.
claims.context: Describes the impact of climate change on ice sheets.

claim_reports.claim_text: Human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming that greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning and deforestation are significant contributors to global warming.

supports.title: Are humans causing or contributing to global warming? - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities, particularly the emission of greenhouse gases, are significantly contributing to the increase in Earth's temperature, which is supported by the consensus among climate scientists.
supports.snippet: Yes, by increasing the abundance of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, human activities are amplifying Earth's natural greenhouse effect.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, as it attributes the observed global warming trend since the mid-20th century to human expansion of the greenhouse effect, primarily through the release of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide from fossil fuel burning and deforestation.
supports.snippet: Each year, human activities release more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than natural processes can remove, causing the amount of carbon dioxide in the ...

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, as it attributes the observed global warming trend since the mid-20th century to human expansion of the greenhouse effect, primarily through the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.
supports.snippet: Human Activity Is the Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gas Concentrations. Over the last century, burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has ...

supports.title: Human Impacts on the Environment: A Focus on Climate Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, as it attributes the observed global warming trend since the mid-20th century to human expansion of the greenhouse effect, primarily through the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.
supports.snippet: Human activities are driving large scale changes in terrestrial and aquatic environments through pollution, water withdrawals, the hunting and harvesting of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect, as multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and the NRDC, explain how human activities, particularly fossil fuel combustion, increase greenhouse gases, disrupting the natural balance and contributing to climate change.

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that the greenhouse effect, primarily driven by greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, is crucial for maintaining Earth's temperature and that human activities have increased these gases, disrupting the natural balance and contributing to climate change.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.

supports.title: Greenhouse Effect 101 - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that the greenhouse effect, primarily driven by human activities such as burning fossil fuels, is a significant factor in climate change due to the increase of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which traps heat and raises temperatures.
supports.snippet: These emissions, made up mostly of carbon dioxide and methane, stem primarily from burning natural gas and oil for heating and cooking, though ...

supports.title: Review Greenhouse gases emissions and global climate change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that greenhouse gas emissions, primarily from fossil fuels, enhance the greenhouse effect, which is a significant driver of global warming and climate change.
supports.snippet: The increase in GHG concentrations as a result of human activity enhances the greenhouse effect, leading to global warming. This process ...

supports.title: Sources of Greenhouse Gas Emissions | US EPA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that the greenhouse effect is a natural process that is being intensified by human activities, particularly through the burning of fossil fuels, which increases greenhouse gas emissions and disrupts Earth's energy balance, leading to climate change.
supports.snippet: The largest source of greenhouse gas emissions from human activities in the United States is from burning fossil fuels for electricity, heat, and ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including NASA and NOAA, which explain the fundamental role of these greenhouse gases in the greenhouse effect.

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide and methane, trap heat near Earth's surface, which is a fundamental aspect of the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.'

supports.title: Basics of the Carbon Cycle and the Greenhouse Effect - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide and methane, warm the Earth by absorbing energy and slowing the rate at which that energy escapes to space, effectively acting as a barrier that traps heat in the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: Due to their ability to absorb infrared radiation, GHG molecules have a significant impact on Earth's climate by acting as a barrier for escaping "heat". For ...

supports.title: Heat-Trapping Pollution - Climate Central
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere, contributing to the greenhouse effect which maintains Earth's temperature.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases warm the Earth by trapping heat near the surface. Heat-trapping greenhouse gases emitted by humans, mainly from burning fossil ...

supports.title: How Exactly Does Carbon Dioxide Cause Global Warming?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly explains that greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide and methane, trap heat in the atmosphere, contributing to the greenhouse effect and raising Earth's surface temperature.
supports.snippet: As carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases heat up the planet, more water evaporates into the atmosphere, which in turn raises the temperature ...

supports.title: Understanding Global Warming Potentials | US EPA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide and methane, warm the Earth by absorbing energy and slowing the escape of that energy into space, effectively acting like a blanket that insulates the Earth.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases (GHGs) warm the Earth by absorbing energy and slowing the rate at which the energy escapes to space; they act like a ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NOAA, confirm that atmospheric CO2 levels have increased by more than 50% since the Industrial Revolution, which clearly supports the claim that CO2 has risen by more than a third since that time.

supports.title: Evidence - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric CO2 levels have significantly increased due to human activities since the Industrial Revolution, with carbon dioxide from these activities rising about 250 times faster than from natural sources after the last Ice Age.
supports.snippet: ... atmospheric CO2 has increased since the Industrial Revolution. Luthi ... 1800s, and is proceeding at a rate not seen over many recent millennia.

supports.title: Carbon Dioxide - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by more than 50% since the start of industrial times in the 18th century, which supports the claim that CO2 levels have risen significantly since the Industrial Revolution.
supports.snippet: With a more than 50% increase in CO2 since the start of industrial times in the 18th century, scientific measurements have linked this increase ...

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric carbon dioxide has increased by more than 50% since the start of the Industrial Revolution, confirming that the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has indeed risen by more than a third since that time.
supports.snippet: Atmospheric carbon dioxide is now 50 percent higher than it was before the Industrial Revolution. ... since the start of the Industrial Revolution in 1750.

supports.title: Carbon dioxide now more than 50% higher than pre-industrial levels
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that carbon dioxide levels have increased by more than 50% since the start of the Industrial Revolution, confirming that CO2 in the atmosphere has risen significantly since that time.
supports.snippet: CO2 levels are now comparable to the Pliocene Climatic Optimum, between 4.1 and 4.5 million years ago, when they were close to, or above 400 ppm ...

supports.title: The History of Carbon Dioxide Emissions | World Resources Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides evidence that carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have significantly increased due to human activities since the Industrial Revolution, indicating that CO2 levels have risen by more than a third since that time.
supports.snippet: From 1850 to the mid-20th century, the world experienced near-constant growth in emissions. This was due largely to industrialization and ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, causing sea levels to rise.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting at an accelerating rate, contributing significantly to sea level rise. Specifically, the combined contribution to global mean sea level has been quantified at 18 mm, with projections indicating further increases by the end of the century.

supports.title: Greenland's Ice Is Melting - UCAR Center for Science Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that both Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets are melting at an accelerating rate, contributing to sea level rise. Specifically, it states that their combined contribution to global mean sea level has been 18 mm, with 10 mm from Greenland and 8 mm from Antarctica, indicating a direct link between ice melt and rising sea levels.
supports.snippet: Earth's warming climate means that overall Greenland loses more ice than it gains each year. Warmer temperatures mean more melt days. During summer, ...

supports.title: Ice Sheets - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting due to global warming, contributing to sea level rise. Specifically, the Greenland ice sheet is losing ice at an accelerated rate, with projections indicating significant contributions to global sea levels by the end of the century.
supports.snippet: As ice melts, the resulting water drains into the ocean and contributes to sea level rise. Antarctica Mass Variation since 2002. 135 billion ...

supports.title: Six ways loss of Arctic ice impacts everyone - World Wildlife Fund
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, which is contributing to rising sea levels. Specifically, the Greenland ice sheet is losing mass rapidly, and its melting is a significant factor in global sea level rise, affecting millions of people worldwide.
supports.snippet: Discover six ways Arctic ice loss affects the planet, including rising sea levels, weather changes, and impacts on wildlife and communities.

supports.title: The Greenland Ice Sheet, Sea Level Rise, and Coastal Communities
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Greenland ice sheet is melting due to global warming, contributing to sea level rise. It states that if the ice sheet were to melt completely, it could raise global sea levels by approximately 7.4 meters (24 feet).
supports.snippet: The Greenland ice sheet alone has the potential to raise global sea levels by an astonishing 23 feet were it to melt away completely.

supports.title: Long-lost Greenland ice core suggests potential for disastrous sea ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Greenland ice sheet is melting due to global warming, contributing to sea level rise. If the ice sheet were to melt completely, it could raise global sea levels by approximately 7.4 meters (24 feet).
supports.snippet: If Greenland's ice sheet were to melt completely, sea levels would rise by about 7 meters (23 feet) causing devastation to the billions who live ...

transcript_data.text: human activities from pollution to overpopulation are driving up the earth's temperature and fundamentally changing the world around us the main cause is a phenomenon known as the greenhouse effect gases in the atmosphere such as water vapor carbon dioxide methane nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons let the sun's light in but keep some of the heat from escaping like the glass walls of a greenhouse the more greenhouse gases in the atmosphere the more heat gets trapped strengthening the greenhouse effect and increasing the earth's temperature human activities like the burning of fossil fuels have increased the amount of co2 in the atmosphere by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution the rapid increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere has warmed the planet at an alarming rate while Earth's climate has fluctuated in the past atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years climate change has consequences for our oceans our weather our food sources and our health ice sheets such as Greenland and Antarctica are melting the extra water that was once held in glaciers causes sea levels to rise and spills out of the oceans flooding coastal regions warmer temperatures also make weather more extreme this means not only more intense major storms floods and heavy snowfall but also longer and more frequent droughts these changes in weather pose challenges growing crops becomes more difficult the areas where plants and animals can live shift and water supplies are diminished in addition to creating new agricultural challenges climate change can directly affect people's physical health in urban areas the warmer atmosphere creates an environment that traps and increases the amount of smog this is because smog contains ozone particles which increase rapidly at higher temperatures exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma heart disease and lung cancer while the rapid rate of climate change is caused by humans humans are also the ones who can combat it if we work to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy sources like solar and wind which don't produce greenhouse gas emissions we might still be able to prevent some of the worst effects of climate change [Music] you
